summary: This is an internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) discussing whether the office should be recused from the criminal investigation into the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and its guards regarding Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. The email concludes there is no basis for recusal and the investigation should proceed.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Author of the email, summarizing discussions about the recusal of the SDNY from the investigation into the MCC following Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Discussion on SDNY Recusal from MCC Investigation
events.description: Internal discussions within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY regarding whether the office should be recused from the criminal investigation into the MCC and its guards relating to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide, due to an ongoing Inspector General (IG) investigation. It was determined there was no basis for recusal.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), prompting a criminal investigation into the facility and its guards.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The email discusses a potential conflict of interest for the SDNY in investigating the MCC regarding Epstein's suicide due to an ongoing Inspector General (IG) investigation.
Senior officials, including an unnamed Inspector General and the Deputy Attorney General's (DAG) office, concluded there was no basis for the SDNY's recusal from the investigation.
The decision was that the SDNY should proceed with the criminal investigation into the MCC and its guards.
The email is dated August 12, 2019, shortly after Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
The correspondence highlights internal DOJ procedural discussions following a high-profile incident.
